body:
Hello @tdamsma! Thanks for updating this PR. We checked the lines you've touched for [PEP 8](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008) issues, and found:



* In the file [`pandas/io/excel/_openpyxl.py`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/dfd6a36f9c0216727d29daa69a475a0808d54418/pandas/io/excel/_openpyxl.py):

> [Line 510:1](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/dfd6a36f9c0216727d29daa69a475a0808d54418/pandas/io/excel/_openpyxl.py#L510): [W293](https://duckduckgo.com/?q=pep8%20W293) blank line contains whitespace
> [Line 512:5](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/dfd6a36f9c0216727d29daa69a475a0808d54418/pandas/io/excel/_openpyxl.py#L512): [E303](https://duckduckgo.com/?q=pep8%20E303) too many blank lines (2)

* In the file [`pandas/tests/io/test_excel.py`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/dfd6a36f9c0216727d29daa69a475a0808d54418/pandas/tests/io/test_excel.py):

> [Line 1215:1](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/dfd6a36f9c0216727d29daa69a475a0808d54418/pandas/tests/io/test_excel.py#L1215): [E302](https://duckduckgo.com/?q=pep8%20E302) expected 2 blank lines, found 1



##### Comment last updated at 2019-03-19 18:55:56 UTC

@WillAyd This is still a work in progress, but feedback would be welcome. I had to make a few adjustments to the tests to be able to run them for a different engine. 
As openpyxl is pretty smart in parsing the excel files to data I decided to not use the TextParser of PythonParser, but (re-implement) some if the api specifically for the OpenPyXL reader. Not sure if this is really desirable, but as the parsers all seem to be meant to deal with text files this felt like the best approach. On my local machine 70 of the 78 tests for openpyxl reader are passing

I think i mentioned this before
but would like to split up the excel.py first to make a subdir then each reader / writer can go in slimmer files

would take a precursor PR to do this
oops, think I missed that. That would certainly help as the file is huge.

@WillAyd I somehow can't comment inline on 

> This should be reverted and just parametrize on `openpyxl` as well

but I really see how this should work with how the tests are set-up now. As i see it the `TestXlrdReader` is responsible for running the `ReadingTestsBase` tests with the 'xlrd' engine. So I added a `TestOpenpyxlReader` class for running the `openpyxl` tests. But as the subclasses are responsible for defining the engine, there is no need for the baseclass to parametrize the engine. In fact this would cause the xlrd specific tests to be run with the openpyxl engine? 

Of course the writer tests follow a different pattern This leads to a pretty complicated decorator like 
```
@pytest.mark.parametrize("engine,ext", [
    pytest.param('openpyxl', '.xlsx', marks=pytest.mark.skipif(
        not td.safe_import('openpyxl'), reason='No openpyxl')),
    pytest.param('openpyxl', '.xlsm', marks=pytest.mark.skipif(
        not td.safe_import('openpyxl'), reason='No openpyxl')),
    pytest.param('xlwt', '.xls', marks=pytest.mark.skipif(
        not td.safe_import('xlwt'), reason='No xlwt')),
    pytest.param('xlsxwriter', '.xlsx', marks=pytest.mark.skipif(
        not td.safe_import('xlsxwriter'), reason='No xlsxwriter'))
])
```

and then every set of engine specific tests need redefine which extension and engine combinations it should run for. I guess judging from the naming (`ReadingTestsBase` vs `_WriterBase`) the sets of read and write tests follow different patterns anyway

@jreback, @WillAyd I completly agree that there are lots of refinements to be made to this code, but I deliberatly did not put too much effort into that because I would like some kind of approval on the general approach before I put a lot of effort into something that may never be merged anyway.


The way this is implemented is that the excel file is read into a dataframe early, and all the keywords like `convert`, `dtype`, `convert_float` etc are dealt with by modifying the dataframe. Because of this some of the parser code needed to be re-implemented, so this is not ideal. An alternative would be to just not support these keywords at all for the openpyxl engine.
The general structure I chose if convert the excel file to a dataframe with openpyxl as soon as possible, and then lots of "silly" code to support keywords like `convert`, `dtype`, `convert_float` etc that make only limited sense here purely for compatibilty.

If you agree with that approach than I will happily work on the code to bring it up to standards. An alternative approach could be to drop support for some keywords in favor of simplicity of the code (but then the set of supported keywords would be engine dependent). 

Finally, I am struggling a bit with some of the tests. Currently 7 are failing, 4 are passing but I can't figure out why e.g. Windows py36_np14 is not working. Any assistance would be much appreciated

I think general approach is fine just want to be cautious of code duplication and complexity, so it's something that can be addressed iteratively during review.

You should be able to click through the logs to see the failure. In this case it's `test_reader_special_dtypes` which you'll see below

https://dev.azure.com/pandas-dev/pandas/_build/results?buildId=8762&view=logs&jobId=60e7d5ab-17b4-5716-5939-f0e150f5044f&taskId=e747a90c-d7dd-5b19-0967-6bf1e91fb8b8&lineStart=692&lineEnd=693&colStart=1&colEnd=1

> @tdamsma can you merge master here?

Done. Unfortunately I haven't had much time/energy work on this lately, but now the python 2.x support is fully dropped I'll look into it again
